statement.text: Ambulatory phlebectomy (microphlebectomy) removes varicose veins through tiny 2-3mm skin incisions using specialized hooks, typically performed as outpatient procedure under local anesthesia with excellent cosmetic results.

explanation.intuition: Instead of one long incision to strip out a vein, phlebectomy uses many tiny pokes (like keyhole surgery) to pull out segments of varicose veins through small holes that heal without stitches and leave minimal scars.
explanation.key_insight: Phlebectomy provides immediate removal of bulging varicose veins with excellent cosmesis. It is typically combined with truncal ablation (thermal or chemical) to treat both the source of reflux and the visible varicosities.
explanation.technical_details: Technique: mark veins standing, tumescent anesthesia, 2-3mm incisions with 11-blade or needle, extract vein with Müller hooks. Incisions: no sutures, Steri-strips or left open. Timing: often same day as truncal ablation. Complications: hematoma, hyperpigmentation, nerve injury, incomplete removal. Alternatives: sclerotherapy for smaller veins. Contraindications: active cellulitis, severe lymphedema, anticoagulation (relative).

procedural_details.technique: Stab incisions 2-3mm with hook extraction of vein segments
procedural_details.combination_therapy: Often combined with truncal ablation same day

clinical_pearls: Mark veins with patient standing before procedure
Tumescent anesthesia provides both analgesia and hemostasis
Often combine with truncal ablation for complete treatment
